The family has left for the day. This is the perfect chance to raid the kitchen! Help Big Pig and friends eat all of the delicious food! If the family comes back before the food is eaten, they’ll surely stop the feast. Got to make it quick!

Each player picks a character to play as and puts the character card in front of them. Then the team of players pick a meal based on difficulty (breakfast for easy, lunch for medium, and dinner for hard). Each meal is a different board with four foods displayed that the players must consume. Each of the foods has 16 tiles that are placed on top of them and each tile has a value. When playing the game, players will munch the foods and be able to remove a total value of tiles equal to their character's hunger value.

Each round a "bad things" card is played. These are events that make the food harder to eat either by having a one time effect or an effect that lasts the whole round. Then the players take their turns, taking one action at a time, and going clockwise. Each character card has 4 actions. To take an action, place a "snack token" on one of the four available actions that does not already have a snack token, and take the action described in that spot. These actions can involve things like munching the food, obtaining an item card for a bonus, or playing a card. When munching a food, remove the tiles from the food board and place them on your character card. The food tiles munched can be used to boost your action cards later. Each action card has a unique effect if it is boosted. After a player takes their turn by performing an action, that player draws action cards up to their hand size.

Play continues until each player has performed their four actions for the turn. Then the car moves forward one space on the game board. If the car reaches the house, the family has returned and stops the feast! All of the players lose. If the car didn't reach the house, players play another round. If at any point the players consume all of the food tiles off of one food, they receive a bonus card that effects each player and gives them a boost. If The players consume every food tile on each of the foods on the whole board, the players immediately win the game!

—description from designer

Name: Happy Little Dinosaurs: Perils of Puberty Expansion Pack
Description:
This expansion adds 54 new cards to the base game, all themed around dinosaur puberty. Your dinosaurs can now face all kinds of new and terrifying problems, including hormones, peer pressure, acne, and worse! Meteors, tar pits, and predators were bad enough—will you survive puberty on top of it all?

The base game is required to play.

Name: Mortal Gods: Kushite Roster & Gifts Card Set
Description:
Absorbed into the vast Persian Empire the Kushite's bring a different type of warrior to the ancient battlefields of Mortal Gods. These fighters can be taken as part of a Persian Sataba, as a stand-alone faction or as mercenaries in a Greek lochos.

This set contains a total of 28 cards made up of Roster Cards to be used to build your Kushite Warban' and 10 Gift Cards specially designed to be used with a Kushite (or a Persian) force.

There are enough cards in this set to make a varied force.

—description from the publisher

Name: Mortal Gods: Omens, Gifts & Injury Card Set
Description:
This set contains 63 Cards in total, including 30 Omens, 30 Gifts and 5 Injury Cards to be used for Mortal Gods. They can also be used by any faction in the game.

Omen Cards
Ancient Greek culture was steeped in tradition, belief and superstition, considered both bad or good with many of these varying from region to region. A vulture flying the wrong way across a battlefield has caused engagements to end abruptly with all participants packing up and returning to their cities. This element has been added to Mortal Gods with the inclusion of the Omens Deck, with the Omens being read as the game progresses.

During play whenever a red Omen marker is taken from the Draw, the player who drew it takes the topmost Omen card from the Omen deck. He then reads the card description aloud before following the rules on the Omen card immediately.

Gifts Cards
In ancient times extraordinarily rare or lucky objects— or people with extraordinary strength or speed—were thought to be gifts from the Gods.
Gifts can be given to a warrior in one of two ways: they either have Gifts already included in their Roster card which is reflected in their initial points value, or you can purchase Gifts for the Warriors of your Lochos by spending roster points to obtain them.

Both Heroes and Companions can be given Gifts. To do this simply include the points value as indicated on the individual Gift cards while rostering your Lochos. You can give a warrior as many Gifts as they have actions and, unless stated on the card, you may only use one Gift per activation.

Injury Cards
Only Heroes gain Injury cards.

If a Warrior sustains more damage than their Resistance score they would usually be removed from the game. Instead Heroes take a Courage check. If it is successful he finds the courage to carry on and takes the top Injury card. The Injury card imposes a penalty for the rest of the game as detailed on the card. If the Hero fails this Courage roll, or already has an Injury card, he is removed as normal from the game. If the damage sustained by the Hero in this instance is caused via critical damage they are automatically dispatched.!

—description from the publisher

Name: Mortal Gods: Persian Roster & Gifts Card Set
Description:
This set contains a total of 46 cards made up of Roster Cards to be used to build your Persian Sataba (warband), 10 Gift Cards specially designed to be used with a Persian force and a single Persian reference card.

There are enough cards in this set to make a varied force.

—description from the publisher

Name: Mortal Gods: Ancient Greek Roster Card Set
Description:
This set contains 97 Greek Roster Cards, including Phalanx Cards to be used to build your locos (warband). They can also be used as Greek Mercenaries or troops from any of the city-states.

There are enough cards in this set to easily make two forces. They are the same Roster Cards as in the Mortal Gods core box set.

—description from the publisher

Name: Mortal Gods: Athenian Card Set & Rules Booklet
Description:
Athenian Card Set & Rules Booklet will provide you with the specific cards and the city-specific rules you need for adding Athenians to your core game of Mortal Gods, including rules for the mighty hero Adronikos, the Defender of Athens.

—description from the publisher

Name: Mortal Gods: Spartan Card Set & Rules Booklet
Description:
This will provide you with the specific cards and the city-specific rules you need for adding Spartans to your core game of Mortal Gods, including rules for the mighty hero Meonas the Harvester, of Sparta.

16-page rules supplement for using a Spartan force as your Lochos
24 x Spartan Roster Cards
5 x Spartan Gift Cards
3 x Spartan Omen Cards

—description from the publisher

Name: Outposts (fan expansion for Carcassonne)
Description:
Tales of dragons harassing the countryside has been told since time immemorial. Dragons have once again been sighted in the countryside and there are rumours that these dragons are destroying more than the livestock in the fields. The nobles of Carcassonne has garrisoned a number of guards in the outposts dotting the countryside in the hopes that the guards there will protect the people in the countryside from the dragons.

Outpost will protect followers from Dragon. A player can sacrifice a follower deployed on an Outpost as a Guard on behalf of the followers that should have been eaten by the Dragon.

—user summary

Name: A Pilot's War
Description:
Feel the need for speed!

"A Pilot's War" is a free, pnp, solo game, which allows you to step into the cockpit of a Fighter jet and experience the thrill of conducting combat missions above enemy territory.

The base game includes two planes, the F-14 Tomcat and the Panavia Tornado. You will fly bombing missions above the Red Sea and Eastern Germany. Survive 20 missions and earn ranks and medals.

This fast paced, action focused game was inspired by Gregory M. Smith's "The Hunters" and Markus Salo's "F-14 Tomcat" and brings the narrative-driven games into the jet age.

Name: Rendezvous im All
Description:
A card game in which you collect rocket parts, assemble them into a rocket and launch it with the matching countdown cards. The opponents can interrupt the launch or cause destruction of the rocket. The player who has collected the most points by assembling and successfully launching rockets wins the game.

—user summary

Name: Strained Kingdoms: Strifull – The Card Game
Description:
STRIFULL tells about the period of the Heretic Wars on the continent of Auslend, in the universe of Strained Kingdoms.

Choose your side, feel yourself on the battlefield amid swords, shields, storms and energetic explosions, and achieve glorious victory…or your own destruction.

Each of the factions has 60 Troop Cards (3 copies of 20 cards), 3 Leader Cards, 4 Tokens (representing the Elemental Stones) and 1 Die. In STRIFULL, players compete against each other while taking on the mantle of one of the Leaders of the chosen faction, crafting strategies and combos to beat the opponent!

Your cards are organized in two 3x3 grids, with your leader character in between them. Each of them has a specific role in the game, one being used to attack your opponent while the other is meant to defend your clan. In your turn, you will move your troops and your leader, use your leader's abilities, recruit new soldiers and engage in battle with the opponent in order to exterminate their lines. The first player to completely overpass all of the opponent's lines is the winner!

—user summary

Name: Late Roman Supplies: A Solo Game
Description:
Northern England in the late 4th century was not a good place to be a Roman, you must escort a supply convoy while fending of attacks from Pictish warriors.

A solo game ideal for 28mm figures but any scale will do as long as the figures are individually based.

Easy to learn but with enough variables to make it still interesting and challenging after multiple games.

Turn Sequence':

     Activate all Roman forces
     Activate all Pictish forces
     Roll for Pictish reinforcements
     Roll for random events


—description from the designer

Name: Seven Galaxies
Description:
Of the plethora of galaxies in the universe, seven of them are primordial. In them are found the Seven Stones of Creation, responsible for all existing power, providing the energy, vitality and balance necessary for everything to exist. The greed for possession of these stones corrupts villages, fuels wars and smolders the sense of justice of those who protect them.

Seven Galaxies is a card game with the theme of intergalactic wars that brings with it new experiences and infinite possibilities, in a universe never seen before. Each player assembles his army in his own way and has the objective of destroying the opponent's fortress to win the battle. For this, there will be several creatures and other auxiliary cards, thus being able to neutralize the enemy and reach its objective. Plays depend on two things: level and energy. Level is what will be used for summoning cards and energy is basically used to activate effects.

During your turn, you will rise your level up, summon creatures, evolve, equip, activate your creatures' abilities to attack your opponent's troops and fortress. The first player to completely destroy the other's fortress wins the game, becoming the most powerful clan in the universe.

Name: The Great Chase
Description:
The NTSB (National Transportation Safety Board) needs your help!

Assignment: travel the world, solve aeronautic crashes, and resolve diplomatic emergencies. Your team's challenge? Completing 10 missions within 10 turns. You will be scored on the quality of your success

Join Miranda Chase and other great characters from M.L. Buchman's techno-thriller novel series in an interactive global aeronautic investigation game! Build a cooperative team of air-crash investigators, select a mission difficulty, and coordinate global travel with your team each turn to determine the best strategy for solving every crisis... but remember: even the finest plans face the roll of the dice!

Players control multiple characters while moving to various locations.  Each game consists of 10 missions which the players must try to solve. The final score is computed based on the number of solved and unsolved missions, flight cards, and time zones.

Name: Illuminare
Description:
Illuminare is an abstract game consisting of only 12 playing cards. Each card is numbered from 1-12 and is divided into 4 quadrants. One player plays as suns and the other as the moons.  The cards quadrants have either suns, moons, or stars, with the stars serving as victory points.

The game lasts 3 rounds. In each round, players are dealt 2 cards each.  They simultaneously choose 1 to give to the opponent. After passing a card, they each play a card simultaneously. the player with the lowest numbered card plays first.

When playing a card, it must be placed out into the "grid" of cards (which begins with 1 starting card) and each card must be played adjacent to another card in the grid.  Players are trying to place their cards so more of their symbols (moon or sun) surround the quadrants with stars.  When a Star area is completely surrounded, the players count their symbols surrounding the stars and the player with the most scores the number of stars as victory points.

—description from designer

Name: Decoratifs
Description:
Decoratifs is an abstract card game for 2 players consisting of only 12 cards with art deco aesthetics.

The cards are divided into 4 quadrants, each quadrant contains 1 to 3 of either of two symbols in the game.  The players are trying to create areas of their connected symbols.  At game's end, each player compares their 3 largest areas, the player who has more large areas wins.

The game consists of 6 rounds.  In each round, players play a card from their hands simultaneously. The cards are numbered from 1-12. The player with the lower number takes the first turn.  On your turn, you must place your card so that one of its corners overlaps the corner of a card in the "grid." You may overlap up to 2 different cards. No card, however, may have more than 2 of its corners covered up.

After playing a card, you replenish your hand by taking one of two face-up cards that were flipped at the start of the round. If you played first this round, you must take the higher numbered card.

After all 12 cards have been added to the grid, players check their three largest areas and the winner is determined.

—description from designer

Name: Trails of Tucana: Ferry
Description:
Supplies for all Trails of Tucana fans! With the Trails of Tucana: Ferry expansion, two new game pads come into play: one with the island maps from the basic game, and one with two new islands.

With the new map, players have two new island maps for Isla Bahía and Isla Habita. On both maps, the ferries help players navigate stretches of sea — and on Isla Habita three additional villages offer new challenges.

Name: Alpujarras Express
Description:
Alpujarras Express is a super quick adaptation of Alpujarras.  The game consists of 30 game cards that are laid out in a path.  It also contains 2 "farmer" cards which, when folded, can stand up and act as pawns.

Players move their farmers along the path and pick up fruit, coins, or market cards.  The market cards are used at the end of the game to "sell" the fruits acquired, so players are trying to pick up market cards that match their fruit cards, while also trying to prevent the opponent from doing the same.

The farmer with the most coins at the end of the game, wins.

Name: The Feds Express
Description:
The Feds Express is a super quick adaptation of The Feds.  The game consists of 36 cards divided into 3 types: agents, mob, police.  The game is played in a series of rounds.

At the start of each round, 2 mob cards are flipped (which show some combination of criminals and contraband.  Players simultaneously play an agent card from the hands, which are numbered from 1-6. The player with the higher agent card chooses a mob card and then replenishes their hand by taking the lower number of 2 available agent cards. After taking a mob card, it is put "into a police car." the police cars show various combinations of criminals and crates. When a player is the first to fill a police car, they take the car.  The first player to take 3 police cars wins.

Name: Navios de Linea: Aboukir, 1798 – 2nd Vol.
Description:
The Battle of the Nile, also known as the Battle of Aboukir Bay, was a major naval battle fought between the British Royal Navy and The First French Republic Navy on August 1-3, 1798, at Aboukir Bay, on the Egyptian Mediterranean coast.

This volume also contains The Battle of Algeciras Bay, the Battle of Lake Erie, and the battles of the American super frigate USS Constitution.

Box contents:

27 ship miniatures
90 removable sails (81 + 9 extras)
9 boards (297 x 210 mm)
1 rules book
2 turns and tables player aids
6 reference cards
3 counter sheets
1 sheet of stickers
6 six-sided dice
1 scenario book

Miniatures are supplied unpainted and some assembly may be required.
